objective.answer: The primary objective of the paper is to propose a novel method leveraging large language models (LLMs) to deduce causal relationships in general causal graph recovery tasks, addressing the limitations of traditional statistical estimation-based methods.
objective.evidence: We propose a novel method that leverages LLMs to deduce causal relationships in general causal graph recovery tasks.

knowledge_gap.answer: The paper addresses the gap in causal graph recovery methods that rely heavily on statistical estimation or expert knowledge, which are often limited by data biases and the complexity of causal reasoning.
knowledge_gap.evidence: Causal graph recovery is traditionally done using statistical estimation-based methods or based on individual’s knowledge about variables of interests. They often suffer from data collection biases and limitations of individuals’ knowledge.

answer: Introduction of a novel RAG-based causal graph recovery method that improves associational reasoning.
Design of an associational reasoning-based prompting strategy to reduce LLMs’ task complexity.
Demonstration of the method's efficacy in overcoming data collection bias issues in traditional methods.
evidence: We introduce a novel RAG-based causal graph recovery method that achieves better associational reasoning.
We design an associational reasoning-based prompting strategy that reduce LLMs’ task complexity to simple associational reasoning to improve the reliability of LLMs’ results.
The method shows its potential in accurate causal graph construction and overcoming data collection bias issues in traditional methods.

inspirational_papers.answer:
- Choi et al. (2022) Their clustering pipeline inspired our filtering model. (Methodological precursors)
- Long et al. (2022) Their direct causal graph output approach was a baseline for our method. (Experimental baselines)
- Kıcıman et al. (2023) Their work on querying LLMs for causal relationships highlighted limitations we addressed. (Papers with limitations addressed by this work)
inspirational_papers.evidence: Most work have a straightforward way of using LLMs. They directly query the causal relationship between each pair of variables (Choi et al., 2022; Long et al., 2022; Kıcıman et al., 2023) by prompting LLMs with the definition of causality, task details and description of the variables of interest.

performance_summary.summary: LACR outperformed baseline LLM methods in causal graph recovery, achieving perfect adjacency precision and recall on the ASIA dataset using background knowledge.
performance_summary.evidence: LACR 1 achieves the best performance when relying solely on BG. It successfully recovers the full skeleton and outperforms the high performance of the pure LLM method.
